item.title: Exceptional finales
item.dc:creator: JeremyROBERT
item.description: A l'issue du Top 8 qui s'est déroulé ce week-end à l'Arena Loire de Trélazé (49), la JDA Dijon et la SIG Strasbourg ont décroché leur place pour la finale. D'autres équipes ont également validé ce dimanche leur billet pour l'Accor Arena. Découvrez le programme complet des finales de la Coupe de France 2024 qui auront lieu les 26 et 27 avril à Paris.
item.content:encoded:
At the end of this weekend’s Top 8 at the Arena Loire in Trélazé (49), JDA Dijon and SIG Strasbourg secured their places in the final. Other teams also booked their tickets for the Accor Arena on Sunday. Discover the full program of the Coupe de France 2024 finals to be held in Paris on April 26 and 27.

The Coupe de France Finals are six matches, six finals, to fill up on basketball throughout a day rich in emotion and spectacle.

Since 1998, the Accor Arena in Paris has been hosting the Coupe de France finals and its 15,000 enthusiastic fans. The atmosphere in the stands is guaranteed by the rhythm of the fanfares and chants. On the field, the players will be giving everything they’ve got to win another title and deliver a top-class performance.

Schedule for the Coupe de France 2024 finals* :

Friday April 26, 2024

6:00 pm – Women’s Trophy Fina
Monaco BA (NF1) – USB Damigny Alençon 61 (NF1)

8:30pm – Men’s Trophy Final
Pays de Fougères (NM2) – CS Gravenchon (NM2)

Saturday, April 27, 2024

9:00am – U18 Women’s Final
USO Mondeville – Lattes Montpellier

11:30am – Final U17 Men
Cholet Basket – ASVEL Lyon Villeurbanne

2:00 p.m. – Women’s Pros final (Trophée Joé Jaunay)
Basket Landes (LFB) – Bourges Basket (LFB)

4:30pm – Men’s Pros Final (Trophée Robert Busnel)
JDA Dijon (Betclic ELITE) – SIG Strasbourg (Betclic ELITE)

*Subject to procedure in progress

Reserve your seats

item.title: Les Bleues set for Tuesday
item.dc:creator: JeremyROBERT
item.description: Le tirage au sort des Jeux Olympiques 2024 se déroulera le mardi 19 mars à 19h au siège de la FIBA. Les chapeaux ont été dévoilées par la fédération internationale et l'Équipe de France féminine figure dans le troisième chapeau.
item.content:encoded:
The draw for the 2024 Olympic Games will take place on Tuesday, March 19 at 7pm at FIBA headquarters. The hats have been unveiled by the international federation, and the French women’s team is in the third hat.

There are only a few days left to wait before we discover Les Bleues’ program for the big Olympic event (July 26 – August 11).

France is in the third hat of the four that will make up the draw on Tuesday evening in Switzerland.

Three groups of four teams will be drawn. The top two from each group and the two best runners-up will then qualify for the quarter-finals. A draw will determine the head-to-head matches.

The specific rules of the draw can be found here :

item.title: Les Bleues’ preparation unveiled
item.dc:creator: JeremyROBERT
item.description: À 144 jours du début des Jeux Olympiques de Paris 2024 (26 juillet au 11 août prochain), Alain Contensoux (Directeur Technique National), Jacques Commères (Directeur de la Performance et des Équipes de France) et Céline Dumerc (General Manager de l’Équipe de France féminine) ont dévoilé ce lundi le programme estival de l’Équipe de France féminine qui se réunira à partir du 6 juin, et qui sera ponctué de cinq rencontres de préparation de très haut niveau.
item.content:encoded:
With 144 days to go until the start of the Paris 2024 Olympic Games (July 26 to August 11), Alain Contensoux (National Technical Director), Jacques Commères (Director of Performance and the French Teams) and Céline Dumerc (General Manager of the French Women’s Team) on Monday unveiled the summer program for the French Women’s Team, which will meet from June 6 and feature five top-level preparatory matches.

Les Bleues know their preparation program for the Paris 2024 Olympic Games. Qualified as the competition’s host nation, the Tricolores will meet again from Thursday June 6 at INSEP (Paris) with the traditional medical check-ups and Media Day. Jean-Aimé Toupane’s players will then head to Anglet (64) for an initial training camp from June 9 to 19.

After a few days’ rest, the players will meet up again in La Roche-sur-Yon (85) on June 23 for the second part of their preparation, which will see them face Finland twice at the Vendéspace (4,000 seats), on Saturday June 29 and Monday July 1.

The Tricolores will then gather in Lyon (69) on July 6 for a new training camp, culminating in a high-level match against Serbia on Friday July 12 at the LDLC Arena (12,000 seats), also the scene of a France-Serbia men’s match on the same day.

Finally, Les Bleues will conclude their preparations with a final training camp in Reims (51) from July 16, where they will play their final warm-up matches before the Olympic Games at the Reims Arena (5,500 seats) on Friday July 19 and Sunday July 21, in a 4-team tournament featuring France, Belgium (European champions in 2023), China (world runners-up in 2022) and Japan (Olympic runners-up in 2021). The direct confrontations between these four teams will be determined following the draw for the Olympic Games, which will take place at FIBA headquarters in Geneva (Switzerland) on March 19.

The French women’s team will then head for Lille on Tuesday July 23 to take up residence in the Lille Olympic Village, just a few days before the start of the competition.

Tickets for Les Bleues’ preparatory matches will go on sale at the end of March/beginning of April.
To be kept informed when tickets go on sale, sign up for the ticketing alert at: https://billetterie.ffbb.com/

item.title: Bosnia Herzegovina-France: out of the trap
item.dc:creator: JeremyROBERT
item.description: Les Bleus sont parvenus à sortir sans encombre du traquenard tendu par la Bosnie-Herzégovine à Tuzla en s’imposant en costaud, 74-64.
item.content:encoded:
Les Bleus came through the Bosnia-Herzegovina trap in Tuzla with a solid 74-64 victory.

Les Bleus came through the Bosnia-Herzegovina trap in Tuzla with a solid 74-64 victory.
Tuzla, even more than Sarajevo, is a basketball town. Playgrounds on every corner and a passion for the national team that saw the 4400 seats in the Mejdan hall snapped up in two short hours. And no doubt several hundred more, as most of the spectators spent the evening standing up in an arena packed to the rafters. Ultras from local club Soboda, dressed all in black, quickly raised the temperature. And calming this volcano became the Bleus’ number-one objective.

While Aziz Bekir continued to bring the centimetres out of his bench, Vincent Collet went for the light cavalry, and after Strazel, Nadir Hifi also made his international debut. A very brief moment of breath in a tough, bitter encounter from which Guerschon Yabusele, overpowering on the rebound, and Isaïa Cordinier, in a more aerial style, often emerged. But it wasn’t enough to open up any kind of gap, as neither team managed to take a lead of more than six points in the first half.

After a pretty marriage proposal at the break, France didn’t go for romance but for defensive impenetrability. Multiplying stolen balls, they finally managed to run. An authoritative 13-0 run in four minutes gave them some breathing space (47-34) and left Bosnia on the verge of a knockout as Jaylen Hoard played his first minutes.

However, former Parisian Amar Gegic kept Bosnia’s hopes alive at the quarter’s buzzer and with an interception later on. And hope is a powerful refuge in which Musa and his team-mates nestled, buoyed by a crowd once again in meltdown, forcing Vincent Collet to stop the bleeding. However, finding their way to the circle remained a challenge: not a basket scored in six minutes as the money-time approached, and free-throws abandoned along the way. But on the other side of the court, the defense didn’t give an inch to the home team and Yabusele and Poirier, in force, ended up imposing their law in the basket.

With their solidity, Les Bleus scored a second decisive victory in the race for EuroBasket 2025, when they face Cyprus, the weakest team in the group, in November.
